DataElement.preferredDefinition: Score range resulting from assessment of five clinical and biochemical domains that comprise the Child-Pugh classification (CPC), a tool used to assess the prognosis of a subject with chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis, and an important parameter affecting the selection of therapy for hepatic disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation._Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete.:A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Used to assess the prognosis of chronic liver disease, mainly cirrhosis. Although it was originally used to predict mortality during surgery, it is now used to determine the prognosis, as well as the required strength of treatment and the necessity of liver transplantation._The difference between the lowest and highest numerical values; the limits or scale of variation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

Concepts.definition: Child-Pugh score indicating one-year survival of 45% in patients with chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.  This score is determined by the study of the following five factors: bilirubin, albumin, international normalized ratio, presence and degree of ascites, and presence and degree of encephalopathy.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/26/2015.
